revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

(1838)

Quél.}} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Mycena aetites'' | hymeniumType=gills | capShape = conical | whichGills = adnate | stipeCharacter=bare | sporePrintColor=white | ecologicalType=saprotrophic | howEdible=inedible }} '''''Mycena aetites''''', commonly known as the '''drab bonnet''',{{cite web |url=http://www.fungi4schools.org/Reprints/ENGLISH_NAMES.pdf |title=Recommended English Names for Fungi in the UK |format=PDF |publisher=[[British Mycological Society]] |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716083053/http://www.fungi4schools.org/Reprints/ENGLISH_NAMES.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-16 }} is a species of [[mushroom]] in the [[Mycenaceae]] family. First described as ''Agaricus aetites'' by Swedish mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]] in 1838, it was assigned its current name in 1872 by [[Lucien Quélet]].{{cite journal |last= Quélet L.|year=1872 |title=Les Champignons de Jura et des Vosges |journal=Mémoires de la [[Société d'Émulation de Montbéliard]] |volume=5 |issue= |page=242}} This rare mushroom is found in Europe. ==Description== The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is a grey-brown color that is somewhat darker in the center. Initially conical in shape, the cap flattens out in maturity to become bell-shaped; the cap can reach a diameter of up to {{convert|2|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}.{{cite book |author=Jordan M. |title=The Encyclopedia of Fungi of Britain and Europe |publisher=Frances Lincoln |location=London |page=162 |isbn=0-7112-2378-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ULhwByKCyEwC|accessdate=2009-09-25 |year=2004}} The stipe of ''M. aetites'' has a pruinose apex and isglabrous below. The mushrooms has an raphanoid odour.{{Cite web|url=http://mycena.no/aetites.htm|title=Mycena aetites|website=mycena.no|access-date=2018-04-04}} A similar species is ''[[Mycena abramsii]]''. This species usually grows on woods and have cheilocystidia with a clear acute-neck. ===Ecology=== ''Mycena aetites'' grows on decayed wood and woody debris in temperate ecosystems. ===Edibility=== ''Mycena aetites'' is considered inedible. It has an indistinct taste, and a faint odor of radish. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q3912823}} [[Category:Mycena|aetites]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1838]] [[Category:Taxa named by Elias Magnus Fries]]
